segments.text: At this point, I've made multiple videos

which are forms of context engineering.
They essentially break down spec driven
development with AI to properly
conceptualize requirements, constraints,
and execution steps before any code is
written. With this approach, you greatly

overall code quality, and results you
typically wouldn't get from just sending
a single prompt into a language model.
And just this week, Google had
introduced their very own specdriven
framework, completely free and easy to
access within Gemini CLI. It's called
Conductor. Conductor is a contextdriven
development framework for Gemini CLI.
Conductor is a tool that helps you plan
before you code by turning your intent
specs as well as constraints into
persistent markdown files alongside your
code. It keeps context out of the chat
logs and inside the repo and it's going
to give AI agents consistent project
awareness. And overall, this is going to

keeping you firm in control. And like I
said, this works perfectly with Gemini
CLI. And for those who do not know what

well as run AI workflows directly within
your terminal. And the best part is is
that this is something that is fully

to pay for APIs because you can access
Gemini models completely for free. It's

contextdriven development as well as AI
assisted coding seamless. So frameworks
like conductor can easily plug in
directly and turn your codebase into a
single source of truth for AI agents.
What's nice is the support for
brownfield projects. Most development
actually happens in existing code bases
and that is where AI tools often
struggle because of their lack of
understanding of project history as well
as the overall architecture context. But
with conductor it is going to address

living set of documents about your

goals. As you add new features or tasks,
Conductor is actually going to be

it's going to allow its knowledge to
grow alongside your project. So, think
of it as a consistent memory as you keep
using your codebase. And what's also
nice is that conductor is also enabled
for team level context. So, you can let

workflow preferences once so that your
AI can generate contributions that
follow the same standards. And overall,
it's going to ensure consistent code
quality, adherance to guidelines, and
smoother onboarding for any sort of
member that is working with your team,
and making features feel like they were
built from a single cohesive team.
